               In the manufacturing processes, the following regulated substances listed in the RMP regulation are used as raw materials, made as intermediates or produced as products.

         Toxics:

            Anhydrous Ammonia
            Formaldehyde Solution
            Methylchloroformate
            Oleum (fuming sulfuric acid)
            Phosgene
            Phoshporus Oxychloride
            Sulfur Trioxide  

         Flammables:

            Monomethylamine
            Dimethylamine
            Trimethylamine
            Dimethylether

Plant property where regulated substances are handled and processed is secured by fence and manned by security personnel at all times.
                                                                                  
WORST-CASE TOXIC RELEASE SCENARIO

          The worst-case release scenario for a toxic regulated substance is a failure of a storage tank containing anhydrous ammonia.  No mitigation is assumed.  This release has off-site impact as determined by use of the EPA OCA Guidance.

WORST-CASE FLAMMABLE RELEASE SCENARIO

         The worst-case release scenario for a flammable regulated substance is a failure

of a storage tank  containing dimethylamine.  No mitigation is assumed.  This release, if ignited, has off-site impact as determined by use of the EPA OCA Guidance and by computer modeling.

ALTERNATIVE TOXIC RELEASE SCENARIOS

         There are seven toxic regulated substances in the RMP.  These are anhydrous ammonia, formaldehyde solution, methylchloroformate, oleum, phosgene, phosphorus oxychloride, and sulfur trioxide.  No mitigation is assumed in assessing off-site impact, except for the oleum release, which is contained in a dike.   The alternative release scenarios are summarized as follows.

         Anhydrous Ammonia - A leak in the ammonia distribution  pipeline.

         Formaldehyde Solution - A leak from the formaldehyde storage tank transfer pump seal. 

         Methylchloroformate - A leak in the transfer pipeline to the process.

         Oleum - A leak of 20% oleum from the oleum tower tank.  The leak is contained in a diked area.  

         Phosgene - A leak in the phosgene pipeline after a vaporizer releasing phosgene vapor. 

         Phosphorus Oxychloride - A leak in the truck unloading hose. 

         Sulfur Trioxide - A leak in the truck unloading hose. 

ALTERNATIVE FLAMMABLE RELEASE SCENARIO

         A release of Trimethylamine from a process transfer line.  The release results in a fireball.  No mitigation or administrative control is assumed.

GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

       The DuPont Belle Plant processes follow the requirements of DuPont Corporate Safety, Health and Environmental (SHE) Standard S21A, "Process Safety Management".  This standard includes and embraces the requirements of 29 CFR 1910.119 and 40 CFR Part 68.
The DuPont Belle Plant safety programs include:

Designing for Safety:
             o  A documented process technology system covering hazards of 
                 materials, equipment design basis, and process design basis.
             o  Extensive accident pr

evention and mitigation systems are
                 strategically located.
             o  Applicable codes and standards are met or exceeded.
             o  Materials of construction are chosen to provide mechanically integrity.
             o  Quality Assurance ensures fabrication in accordance with design 
                 specifications and proper assembly

Maintaining our Plant:
             o  Maintenance personnel are trained and experienced.
             o  Contractors are trained and qualified.
             o  A work permit system controls hazards.

Operating Safely:
             o  Operators are trained and job qualified.
             o  Technical resources are available and utilized as  required.
             o  Operators follow approved procedures.

Auditing our Operations:
             o  Routine safety inspections are conducted.
             o  Corporate, independent and governmental audits and reviews are conducted.
             o  Process Hazards Analyses are conducted.
             o  Critical safety equipment is set up on a periodic inspection frequency 
                 to ensure ongoing mechanical integrity.
             o  Pre-startup safety reviews are conducted prior to starting up any new 
                 or modified equipment.
             o  Quality assurance of critical equipment ensures fabrication in 
                 accordance with design specifications.
             o  All incidents are investigated and actions taken to prevent recurrence.


THE FIVE-YEAR HISTORY

          No deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known off-site deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage have resulted from a release of any of the regulated chemicals from the covered processes under 40 CFR Part 68.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

          Plant personnel are trained and equipped to respond to releases of the regulated substances.  The program is summarized as follows:

Training a

nd Preparation

             o  Plant personnel receive emergency response training.
             o  Plant emergency responders are trained.
             o  Emergency response plans are current.
             o  Plant participates in emergency drills
             o  Critiques are held on drills and actual events.
             o  The DuPont Belle Plant is a member of the local emergency planning committee.

If a Major Release Occurs

             o  Emergency alarm is sounded.
             o  Plant Emergency Operating Center is activated.
             o  Plant Incident Commander and emergency squad respond.
             o  Community emergency responders are notified as appropriate.


PLANT CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY
            
As part of the Belle Plant process hazards review program, all processes are thoroughly reviewed on a specific periodic basis to identify risk reduction opportunities to improve safety.  As a result of these reviews, the following improvements are planned.

For Phosphorus Oxychloride:

        o   Upgrade interlock system for the unloading, storage and distribution
             of phosphorus chloride and upgrade emergency response and spill 
             control procedures.

        o   Reduce consequences associated with a large vapor release from
            process equipment.

For Anhydrous Ammonia:

        o   Upgrade controls and procedures to prevent "roll-over" and potential
            damage of the storage tank due to unloading a large quantity of warm
            ammonia.

        o   Upgrade interlock system and safety design of boom and hydraulic
             cylinders on barge unloading.

        o   Implement program to periodically monitor equipment/foundation for
             differential settlement to prevent excessive stress on equipment and
             potential damage.

        o   Upgrade pressure relief system on storage tank annular space.

        o   Improve integrity/reliability of flare that controls emissions

from storage tank.

        o   Upgrade transfer systems, processes and facilities to reduce the
             release quantity due to catastrophic failure and limit offsite exposure.

        o   Upgrade the temperature control system to reduce the potential hazards of
            equipment overpressure and also to prevent low temperature ammonia from
            entering the transfer pipeline.
